Description: Head of M. Antonius right, bearded; around, inscription. Border of dots. (obverse)

Hercules seated facing on rock, holding spear in right hand and sword in left hand, with lion-skin draped over lap; on right, shield decorated with gorgoneion; on left, inscription; on right, inscription. Border of dots. (reverse)
State: Associated with: Roman Republic Ancient Greece and Rome: Roman Republic
Curator's comments: Antony claimed that his family, the Antonii, were descended from Anton, a son of Herakles invented for the purpose.
Bibliographic references: RR1 / Coins of the Roman Republic in the British Museum: vol. 1 aes rude, aes signatum, aes grave, and coinage of Rome from B.C. 268. (4255, p.578)
Walker & Higgs 2001 / Cleopatra of Egypt: from History to Myth (247)
PCR / Principal coins of the Romans: Volume I: The Republic c. 290 - 31 BC; Volume II: The Principate 31 BC - AD 296; Volume III: The Dominate AD 294 - 498. (260)
Ghey, Leins & Crawford 2010 / A catalogue of the Roman Republican Coins in the British Museum, with descriptions and chronology based on M.H. Crawford, Roman Republican Coinage (1974) (494.2.1)
Associated names: Named in inscription & portrayed: Mark Antony
